Message.Title: The Game Changer Will Be A Not-For-Profit Online Retailer
Message.Msg: Soon an online retail site will appear that will be run as a non-profit or will donate all profits to charity, similar to the way Newman’s Own is run. It is just a matter of years, not generations. This will be the ultimate way for manufacturers to get their product out to consumers without being gouged by traditional retailers. And people will flock to this site for price and for the charitable aspect. Bezos knows this is coming, so that is why he is desperately expanding as fast as he can. Once this takes off, it will severely crimp Amazon, EBay and even Walmart.

Message.Title: Where will amzn be with the next decline in the market
Message.Msg: This is from hussmannfunds, longs declaring victory with a forward PE of 160 is absurd to be honest, of course if they sell and walk away that is different. Reminds me of the longs when Nasdaq was at 5000. If AMZN made money I would congratulate the longs and walk away from my position, but there are no such earnings to support this ridiculuos price. "The historical instances corresponding to the above conditions represent a chronicle of overextended bull market rallies, where investors would typically have been quite incorrect to declare victory at halftime: December 1972 - January 1973 (followed by a 48% collapse over the next 21 months) August - September 1987 (followed by a 34% plunge over the following 3 months) July 1998 (followed abruptly by an 18% loss over the following 3 months, and at the beginning of a nearly 14-year period where the S&P 500, including dividends, has underperformed Treasury bills, with the S&P 500 nearly 30% lower four years later) July 1999 (followed by a 12% market loss over the next 3 months, and a series of whipsaw recoveries and losses, with the S&P 500 over 40% lower three years later) January 2000 (followed by a spike 10% loss over the next 6 weeks, a series of whipsaw recoveries and losses, and finally a bear market that took the S&P 500 over 45% below its Jan 2000 level by late 2002) March 2000 (followed by a spike loss of 12% over 3 weeks, and a 49% loss into 2002) July 2007 (followed by a 57% market plunge over the following 21 months) January 2010 (followed by a 7% "air pocket" loss over the next 4 weeks, with a recovery into April and then a renewed decline, leaving the S&P 500 about 11% lower by July) April 2010 (followed by a 17% market loss over the following 3 months) December 2010 (near the start of QE2, and followed by a 10% further advance in the S&P 500 into May 2011, when an additional syndrome emerged that was also observed last week – see Extreme Conditions and Typical Outcomes – whereupon an 18% market plunge wiped out the entire gain, and then some). March 2012 (followed by a further advance of about 3% over the following 3 weeks, and then a quick if unmemorable market decline of nearly 10%). "

Message.Msg: If you short now, get some protective calls...and keep rolling those calls higher so you lock in the "long" profits. One the other hand, Bezos must realize with sales tax ending and major competitors starting to directly challenge AMZN, he must find new revenue sources before his "growth" story falls apart. Message.Title: Shock & Awe
Message.Msg: AMZN is up 6% so far and we are going into a critical earnings report that is shaping up to be another disappoint. I am truly amazed. Okay, I'd like to layout some of the bear case points and I'd like some rational counter arguments from the bulls: -Sales growth is decelerating -Holiday sales have disappointed exceptions... Comscore expected 16% yoy on-line growth and it came in 14%... btw, analysts that follow amzn are forecasting 27% growth. -Amzn has missed eps estimates 2 quarters in a row. In fact, they had negative net margins last quarter If they don't hit $0.27 they will miss for a 3rd time in a row! -Operating and net margins are trending down. -Payroll tax just went up -CA, TX and other states are now collecting sales tax -France and England are after AMZN for $100's of millions in taxes. Not an insignificant sum given AMZN's thin to negative margins. -They face incredibly strong competition. GOOG, APPL, ORCL, WMT, etc. Target just announced a year-round price match program. -It has lofty valuation marges... TTM PE is over 3k. There are plenty of reasons to stay away from this stock. Why stay in it, let alone bid it up? I am profoundly confused by this price action.

Message.Title: Nuking AMZN Cashflow
Message.Msg: So, someone somewhere claim that one reason AMZN can show a good cash flow is to squeeze suppliers on term of payments. That is, AMZN can demand to take longer time to pay suppliers due to its clout. Now, one way the competition (for example, BBY, COST, TGT, WMT, etc) can go at AMZN is to turn around and offer key suppliers better and more competitive payment terms than what AMZN can offer. AMZN at some point will have to meet the better terms at the supplier levels. Hell, a "game over, AMZN" move would be for COST and WMT to pull exclusive deals. COST and WMT certainly got the clout and the mojo to pull that play off. Can you imagine how AMZN cash flow would look? ;)
